The gravitational force acting on the drop is given by F_g = ρ V g, where ρ is the density of water, V is the volume of the drop, and g is the acceleration due to gravity.
The surface tension force acting on the drop is given by F_s = σ l, where σ is the surface tension of water and l is the length of the separation between the drop and the nozzle.
The volume of the drop is given by V = (4/3) π r^3, where r is the radius of the drop.
The length of the separation between the drop and the nozzle is given by l = d, where d is the diameter of the nozzle.
Setting the gravitational force equal to the surface tension force, we have: ρ (4/3) π r^3 g = σ d
Solving for r, we get: r = ((3 σ d)/(4 ρ g π))^(1/3)
